Over the Christmas break, Charlie and I had a lot of spare time to catch up on movies. Sounds like the perfect opportunity to catch up on all those recent releases I haven‚Äôt had time to see, right?Because it turns out, I couldn‚Äôt sit through more than 5 minutes of a lot of said movies and ended up simply rewatching older films that I already knew I enjoyed. And my goodness this made me realise just how different movies have become in the last fifteen years or so. Now, this of course isn‚Äôt to say that all modern movies are bad or that everything produced in the past was a banger (#notall) BUT I will say that there was a discernible difference that kept coming up in everything I watched.Older films, even action flicks, just seemed to care more about having human relationships at their heart. No matter whether it was about terrorists at a Christmas party or a quest for the Holy Grail, these films made the conflict centre on family, friendship and love. Granted, sometimes this was done in a flawed way (*cough* Ocean‚Äôs Eleven *cough cough*). The central themes weren‚Äôt so concerned with subverting an existing narrative or grand venture in saving the world. No, they were simply personal stories of people pushed to their limits.

Newsletter Name: Boy Movies Newsletter Description: credit: Sarah TurbinWhat is Boy Movies?Boy Movies is a weekly newsletter by Allison Picurro (that‚Äôs me, hi!) based on a joke I‚Äôve had with myself for years about the binary between boy movies (think Taxi Driver, Ghostbusters, the complete works of Michael Bay) and girl movies (think Mamma Mia!, Lady Bird, the complete works of Nancy Meyers). I myself am not a boy but I am a great lover of boy movies, so you can imagine the ways I‚Äôve struggled over the years with my appreciation of them and what it says about me. Here, I‚Äôll attempt to reckon with it all by unpacking what makes a boy movie a boy movie, the specific ways movies are marketed toward men, what it is about boy movies that appeals (or doesn‚Äôt) to the rest of us, and more. Sometimes I welcome guests, sometimes I have contributors, sometimes I do themed months, and sometimes, when I‚Äôm in a silly mood, I write about girl movies. Mostly I‚Äôm just trying to have fun and eventually sell out to a major corporation in order to achieve my ultimate end goal of early retirement. Okay, sure, but who are you?Well, like I said, I‚Äôm Allison Picurro. I‚Äôm a writer, currently at TV Guide. I have bylines at Decider and IndieWire, and I used to work at HBO. I tweet, despite being raised in a loving home. I make pithy little quips on Letterboxd. I am not Al Pacino. (As far as you know!!!)Why subscribe?If you subscribe, you get a newsletter in your inbox every Tuesday full of my thoughts on movies. Maybe you‚Äôre in an Intro to Film class and you want to argue with your male professor. Maybe you also love Top Gun: Maverick. Maybe you just want to hang out with me. Either way, welcome. Anyway, let‚Äôs move on to the trailers that caught my eye.Movie Blurb:

My life is like a movie and I do my own stunts. If you hear that I slapped someone, it‚Äôs probably because it‚Äôs me. A good movie makes the audience feel like they‚Äôve journeyed with the characters. So if you feel a sting on your left cheek, it‚Äôs just because of great writing on my part.Life is just like a movie, the characters come and go as seen in the movies. But there is a difference, movies last only three hours. Ours last a little too long and there are no end credit scenes. Life is like a camera, focus on what‚Äôs important and capture the good times. You‚Äôll be able to delude yourself. Life is like a movie. Write your own ending, keep believing, keep pretending. The older I get, the more I realize that not everything always goes as planned, but this is not some fairy tale movie. This is real life and things happen. No good movie is too long, and no bad movie is short enough.

We were out of town over the weekend in Indianapolis because Son #1 got Hubby Steelers vs. Colts tickets for Christmas. Most of you know how that game turned out (sorry John and Staci). Anyway, we still had a fantastic time seeing him and his girlfriend and enjoyed Christmas lights, a little shopping (there was a chocolate shop just up the street!), and great food.I thought I‚Äôd share our favorite Christmas movies with you today. There are plenty out there, and our choices may tell you a little about our personalities. When Hubby and I were first married, he was shocked I‚Äôd never seen It‚Äôs a Wonderful Life. Nearly thirty-six years later, I‚Äôve seen it that many times. Our sons were never crazy about it, but still watched with us.
